content.raw:
I was very proud of a new robot that I made in the model editor. Its name is BlockheadBot and I made it by editing Robonaut and replacing the head link with a simple block shape textured with bricks. However, when I exited, the head started swinging around wildly because I had attached it with a ball joint, causing the arms to swing. When I re-entered the model editor to change the joint type, this is how BlockheadBot looked:

https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2397858354-blockhead.png


After overwriting my old model in this session, it appears that this is the new starting pose for BlockheadBot, since whenever I reset the world it goes back to that position (floating in space and tilted).
content.html:
I was very proud of a new robot that I made in the model editor. Its name is BlockheadBot and I made it by editing Robonaut and replacing the head link with a simple block shape textured with bricks. However, when I exited, the head started swinging around wildly because I had attached it with a ball joint, causing the arms to swing. When I re-entered the model editor to change the joint type, this is how BlockheadBot looked:

https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2397858354-blockhead.png

After overwriting my old model in this session, it appears that this is the new starting pose for BlockheadBot, since whenever I reset the world it goes back to that position (floating in space and tilted).

content.raw:
Ahh humm maybe this is because I asked Ian to edit the model at its current pose. I was thinking of mobile robots, if it moves very far away from its initial pose and you try to edit it, it seems like it just disappeared, because it would go back to the initial position and maybe you're too zoomed in to see it.

I'm not sure what would be the best solution here. Maybe leave it at the original pose but move the camera there?

However, I can think of a case when the user carefully placed a lot of models, then tries to edit one of them and it moves to the pose it was originally placed at, and it ends up on top of something else making it difficult to edit...

Another idea is to have a button just to make the model upright at the current position... Overkill?
content.html:
Ahh humm maybe this is because I asked Ian to edit the model at its current pose. I was thinking of mobile robots, if it moves very far away from its initial pose and you try to edit it, it seems like it just disappeared, because it would go back to the initial position and maybe you're too zoomed in to see it.

I'm not sure what would be the best solution here. Maybe leave it at the original pose but move the camera there?

However, I can think of a case when the user carefully placed a lot of models, then tries to edit one of them and it moves to the pose it was originally placed at, and it ends up on top of something else making it difficult to edit...

Another idea is to have a button just to make the model upright at the current position... Overkill?

content.raw: Oh true! Humm, maybe just remove the message altogether? I think the expected behaviour is that it would be editable. @spaepcke ?
content.html: Oh true! Humm, maybe just remove the message altogether? I think the expected behaviour is that it would be editable. @spaepcke ?

content.raw: I think [this](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1408/model-editor-inspectors/diff#comment-4999734) scale updating issue was broken
content.html: I think this scale updating issue was broken

This block shows up quite a lot. How about doing something like

std::string GetLeafName(std::string _name)
{
  std::string leafName = _name;
  size_t idx = name.find_last_of("::");
  if (idx != std::string::npos)
    leafName = name.substr(idx+1);
  return leafName;
}

content.raw:
I'm not being able to reproduce it now, but at some point when I left the editor, all manipulation handles were visible at the same time on top of the saved model. 

I have to check better when `SetModelVisible` is being called to see if I can reproduce it. But it might be worth it to check if we're not setting any non-visual children visible here.
content.html:
I'm not being able to reproduce it now, but at some point when I left the editor, all manipulation handles were visible at the same time on top of the saved model.

I have to check better when SetModelVisible is being called to see if I can reproduce it. But it might be worth it to check if we're not setting any non-visual children visible here.

content.raw:
1. Insert a sphere, edit

1. In edit mode, scale it down using the scaling tool

1. Open the inspector, change the visual to mesh and apply, the visual becomes a unit box, ok

1. Change it back to sphere and apply, it becomes a sphere in the same scaled size it was before

1. Now Save and Exit, the sphere is not scaled in the saved model
content.html:
1. Insert a sphere, edit

  2. In edit mode, scale it down using the scaling tool

  3. Open the inspector, change the visual to mesh and apply, the visual becomes a unit box, ok

  4. Change it back to sphere and apply, it becomes a sphere in the same scaled size it was before

  5. Now Save and Exit, the sphere is not scaled in the saved model

content.raw:
If I scale a mesh visual via the inspector, the scaling is saved. But if I scale a collision, it is saved at the original scale.

But I know we'll be dealing with mesh scaling on a future PR, so it's fine if this is tackled then.
content.html:
If I scale a mesh visual via the inspector, the scaling is saved. But if I scale a collision, it is saved at the original scale.

But I know we'll be dealing with mesh scaling on a future PR, so it's fine if this is tackled then.

content.raw: Looking more carefully, it seems like these objects get handled by QT. So they should be deleted when the windows closes, correct?
content.html: Looking more carefully, it seems like these objects get handled by QT. So they should be deleted when the windows closes, correct?

content.raw: I haven't thoroughly checked, but we should make sure these pointers get properly deleted. It looks like this function creates a new pointer, and then passes it off. This type of pattern could benefit from a smart pointer.
content.html: I haven't thoroughly checked, but we should make sure these pointers get properly deleted. It looks like this function creates a new pointer, and then passes it off. This type of pattern could benefit from a smart pointer.

Here would be a great place for an assert:

else
{
    GZ_ASSERT(response->type() == msg.GetTypeName(), "Received incorrect response from 'world_sdf' request.");
}
